10.16.text: So, what I wanted to talk to you guys about today was a little bit

16.09.text: about what we do at Planet Labs and why and a little bit of some

20.09.text: of the lessons I've learned on this entrepreneurial journey,

23.90.text: if you like, for others that are interested

28.51.text: I hope it will be useful,

30.18.text: but much of it will be from my personal perspective,

32.23.text: so take it with that grain of salt.

34.59.text: I want to start us here, this is called the Earth.

38.10.text: You may have seen it before.

40.68.text: You may have seen it before in particular,

42.87.text: because of this rather iconic image that the Apollo 17 astronauts

47.14.text: took when they were hurtling around the moon in 1972.

50.34.text: It was the first full -- first full frame image of the

54.06.text: entire planet when it was fully sunlit and it's credited

59.44.text: with having started the green movement,

61.91.text: but not so much because we didn't know we were living on

64.53.text: a planet before then or at least most people thought we did.

68.77.text: It is the case though that it hadn't really gone into the public

73.48.text: consciousness and this changed a lot of peoples thinking,

78.17.text: because they saw the thin shadow of the atmosphere,

80.53.text: they saw the Earth in the vastness of space and made people realize

84.41.text: that we've got to take care of this beautiful planet that we're on.

88.73.text: But beautiful as this picture is, it's a little bit lacking.

91.85.text: It's lacking because it's static and the Earth is constantly changing

96.35.text: as we -- in particular affect the planet as human beings and what

102.44.text: one would ideally like is much more high-cadence imagery,

109.70.text: So satellite imagery today is typically old.

112.34.text: The imagery you find online is typically several years old.

116.39.text: So we did a thought experiment.

119.63.text: if we could take a high-resolution image of every single

122.12.text: point on the Earth's surface, every single day.

125.72.text: What could we do with that data?

129.43.text: We were thinking well, we could track deforestation.

132.15.text: We could see that as it happens rather than waking

134.95.text: up at the end of the year and realizing there is

136.57.text: a bloody great hole in the Amazon again.

139.22.text: We could catch people in the act as the

142.83.text: logging takes place over many weeks.

145.35.text: We could do the same for fisheries.

147.57.text: We could see disasters like the situation happening in Nepal

151.14.text: right now and help people quickly get the imagery they need

154.83.text: to figure out how to respond to those situations.

158.71.text: Same with floods, fires, earthquakes -- well that is an earthquake,

165.45.text: We would also be able to help people improve agricultural yield,

168.89.text: because with satellite data you can

171.24.text: tell biomass in every single pixel,

174.54.text: and so we could help people improve agriculture around the world.

176.91.text: And then there are a lot of commercial applications for example,

179.99.text: having up-to-date imagery is something that people want on their consumer

183.09.text: mapping products and so if everyone wants that on their phone,

186.16.text: instead of an image several years old,

187.73.text: they want the image from recently and there

190.17.text: is lots of financial applications as well.

192.86.text: And so me and my co-founders who were at NASA at the time

196.35.text: left NASA to start a company to try and tackle that problem

199.30.text: of trying to get to daily imaging of the planet.

201.58.text: And so that was the mission we set out, image the whole Earth,

206.17.text: every single day and provide universal access to that imagery.

212.63.text: And so roughly what does that take?

214.67.text: It takes a system like this.

216.08.text: We need about a 150 satellites orbiting

219.28.text: the Earth in a particular orbit.

221.15.text: We need a system of 30 ground stations all round the world

223.68.text: to receive the information down from those satellites.

226.55.text: We need of course large numbers of processors in

229.50.text: order to digest and make that information calibrated

234.24.text: and georectified onto the Earth's surface,

236.73.text: so that it's useful for consumers.

238.64.text: And then we thought about two ways of sort

240.76.text: of provisioning that out to customers.

242.67.text: One, via sort of feed hoses to large enterprise users,

248.02.text: say those consumer mapping clients that I was talking about,

252.25.text: but also we wanted to get it out on a platform

254.28.text: so that everyone could have access to it.

256.35.text: So we have an open API where anyone can come and hack

259.28.text: their own apps on our imagery, on our servers.

262.58.text: So that's roughly what we set out to do.

266.00.text: This little video is going to show you how it would work.

269.94.text: So we put 150 satellites into a sun-synchronous plane,

273.14.text: that -- they're all in the same plane.

276.16.text: that plane stays fixed with respect to the

277.51.text: sun and the Earth rotates underneath it.

280.13.text: Each one is pointing down and taking a strip of imagery

283.02.text: along the ground and then by the time the next one comes

286.27.text: along the Earth is rotated just the width of the image.

289.17.text: So that it stripes the part just next to it.

293.04.text: It ends up being like a line scanner for the planet.

296.40.text: So basically the Earth does the legwork and we just stay put

301.79.text: and let the Earth rotate underneath it and slowly scan it,

304.66.text: a line scanner for the planet.

305.96.text: This is two of our satellites being deployed

310.01.text: It gives you a bit of a sense of scale of how small our satellites

312.77.text: are versus the solar arrays of the space station.

316.26.text: And I'm going to tell a little bit is that -- about what

320.97.text: it took to get there and some of the journey first.

323.66.text: So we started this in our garage as Silicon

327.33.text: Valley start-ups are want to do.

330.83.text: But I think we were the first space start-up to do that.

333.66.text: We literally built our first satellite in our garage and that

337.10.text: wasn't the only lesson we learned from Silicon Valley.

339.58.text: We took an approach of rapid iteration, we call it agile aerospace.

344.09.text: I'll tell you a little bit more about that in a minute.

347.31.text: We try to just take things out into the field and test them;

351.06.text: we would take our satellites out.

352.46.text: We'd fire them in planes over our ground stations to check they work,

356.56.text: have the radio tests along across the Valley

359.91.text: from here to basically the Lick Observatory,

363.24.text: we would send somebody up there and try and to

365.38.text: do a link and make sure everything worked.

367.19.text: So we took this sort of more hands-on and testing approach,

370.22.text: which is quite different from the aerospace sector

373.51.text: which takes a very hardcore analytical approach to

377.33.text: finding problems and risks to the satellite design.

382.19.text: So we started in our garage and that

384.16.text: was just over three years ago, 3.5 years ago,

387.49.text: and we -- actually the founders of our company

391.52.text: we all met at the United Nations at a conference that

395.25.text: was looking at how to use satellites to help humanity?

398.44.text: How can we bring them to help people in developing countries,

401.40.text: help stop disasters, things like that?

403.39.text: And so this in many ways has been the uniting theme throughout

406.30.text: our careers so we've known each other for about 15 years

409.02.text: before starting this company and so we were long-term friends

413.24.text: and cared about this overarching mission.

417.85.text: So what was standing in our way?

419.82.text: The first thing that was standing in our

421.62.text: way was that satellites look like this.

423.99.text: You see these people, they're rather big the satellites,

427.97.text: either that or the people are very small.

429.75.text: So these satellites weigh about six tons,

433.76.text: It was launched last year by NASA.

436.70.text: This is what a traditional Earth imaging satellite looks like.

447.87.text: It was launched on a single rocket.

450.39.text: And satellites like this have done a tremendous service

454.60.text: in helping us to understand the planet so far.

458.05.text: And this is -- this sort of satellite has given

459.91.text: us reliable data over the last 40 years.

461.96.text: But if you want to put up 150 satellites,

467.12.text: because well at least not unless you have a gigantic budget.

471.69.text: But that doesn't really represent the forefront of satellite technology

475.46.text: at least small satellite technology which really was represented

479.26.text: prior to us at least by these folks at Surrey Satellites,

483.48.text: who are actually from the U.K.

485.96.text: and these are some of their satellites that they build,

489.78.text: a rapid eye is the constellation of satellites that

492.16.text: they built here shown and these satellites are about

503.68.text: But even that for us was that not going to work.

507.07.text: We needed to put up 150 of these guys and even by that standard it was

510.24.text: going to be billions of dollars and not something we could get venture

513.51.text: capital funded let alone try and start out of our own pockets,

516.95.text: which is what we wanted to do.

518.83.text: So what we did was make satellites much smaller and this

521.55.text: is actually one of our satellites under construction by one

524.80.text: of our engineers to give you a bit of sense of scale.

528.20.text: So our satellites -- this is actually one of them, what it looks like.

531.45.text: One of the dominant features you can see is actually,

534.68.text: we have an artist in residence who paints all of our satellites

538.26.text: and this is actually the top side of the solar array,

541.25.text: so you can't see the main solar array obviously

543.00.text: that has to have the solar cells on it,

545.76.text: but the artist gets to paint the other parts,

550.70.text: So we've miniaturized a massive amount

552.94.text: of technology into this little volume.

558.81.text: They use what's called the CubeSat form factor,

560.91.text: which actually Stanford engineers were involved

566.67.text: It's basically a standard form factor of size of a satellite.

570.26.text: And launch providers got used to this form factor to give --

575.88.text: which enabled us to get more access to space basically.

579.42.text: But inside that is first and foremost the largest

582.44.text: telescope we could possibly fit into that volume.

585.01.text: So to the front two thirds of the satellite

589.54.text: which is the optics that you need to get reasonable resolution

593.09.text: imagery of the ground from 400 or 500 kilometers up,

597.33.text: which is where we are orbiting.

600.54.text: Then we have a camera system at the back,

603.15.text: which that telescope feeds to and on our latest

612.32.text: But in addition to that that's only really just the beginning

615.07.text: what one has to have is obviously the power systems so the

617.96.text: batteries and the solar power to keep them charged.

621.75.text: We have to have an attitude determination system so that is the system

626.63.text: that figures out where the satellite is and where it's pointing.

629.65.text: So we have a GPS antenna that picks up

633.64.text: that and actually GPS works in space.

635.50.text: You might question whether it would or not, but it does.

638.31.text: We're that much lower than the GPS satellites, so it still works.

642.23.text: And we have a star camera which looks out up whilst the main cameras

647.84.text: looking down and takes pictures of the star field and then automatically

652.18.text: recognizes constellations and then adds metadata to our main image

658.11.text: to say you were pointed this way when you took that image.

663.00.text: the GPS stamp says where it's at in the orbit

666.14.text: and then this the star camera stamp,

668.65.text: if you like, says which way are we pointing at the time?

671.32.text: There is a lot of other sensors in here.

673.49.text: There is a three axis accelerometer, three axis rate gyro,

677.75.text: these all feed into a Kalman filter to spit out

680.86.text: the satellite position and attitude state.

683.52.text: Then we have a system of attitude control, so that's what then says,

690.32.text: we now know where we are pointing,

691.46.text: now we need to point somewhere else,

692.80.text: at the ground say if we're pointing up or what have you.

695.46.text: And so we have two systems of attitude control,

698.56.text: one is a system of reaction wheels.

700.58.text: So these are little brush-less DC motors essentially that were

704.42.text: put in all three axis and if you spin them one way then the satellite

713.31.text: has to spin the other way to conserve momentum and so we can turn

716.31.text: the satellite round just by turning on these motors.

719.59.text: We have an independent other system of attitude

721.71.text: control which is using magnetorquer coils.

724.83.text: So these are little -- just literally wire -- a system of copper wire that

731.18.text: we put through a little current which creates a little B field,

735.97.text: which reacts against the Earth's really small magnetic field and

739.95.text: gives just enough torque to turn our satellites round as well.

742.58.text: So we have two independent means of turning our satellites around.

745.57.text: One is completely simple that magnetorquer coil,

748.90.text: very robust, but it's a little bit slower.

752.67.text: And so when we're turning for example to point at our ground

754.94.text: station to maximize the gain of our radio antenna,

759.44.text: But for most of the time we can use our magnetorquer coils.

762.53.text: Also in there we have a processor.

765.88.text: we have an FPGA which does the initial compression of the imagery.

768.78.text: We have a full up x86 processor running Ubuntu,

774.62.text: and then we have also got an ARM processor that does a lot

778.46.text: of the light work scheduling of the satellite operations.

783.32.text: And so actually despite being some of the smallest satellites ever,

786.73.text: they are some of the most capable satellites

790.16.text: ever in terms of the compute power on-board.

792.39.text: We've got more memory and processing

793.94.text: power than a lot of other satellites,

795.50.text: if not all of them just because we use the latest technology

799.07.text: and stuff it in and we take a slightly higher risk

801.19.text: approach which I'll be talking more about.

805.15.text: Then we have a radio systems to send down the data,

808.50.text: so we have three radios on board all of which we developed in-house,

812.40.text: because the cheapest radio we could find that would

815.37.text: do the job was larger than our satellite and,

820.28.text: So it was out of scope on two axes.

822.37.text: So we built our own radio in-house

823.96.text: that we have - it has three channels,

827.28.text: a UHF channel, which does the command and control of the satellite,

832.39.text: an S band which is where we send the

834.15.text: data up and an X band which is 8.3

836.36.text: gigahertz to send the data down.

838.28.text: We can send our data down at about 40 megabits a second down to

841.94.text: our ground stations around the world and I will show you a little

844.69.text: bit what the ground stations look like in a minute as well.

847.78.text: So that's what the satellite looks like.

849.43.text: And as I mentioned, we take this sort of agile approach and what

853.61.text: I mean by that is we constantly put in the latest technology.

857.36.text: So in between the last two -- the one we just launched

861.32.text: about a month ago today well we launched 14 satellites

865.05.text: and we always put a tech demo satellite on,

867.68.text: testing our next generation technology and then

870.20.text: we put a fleet of ones that we know would work.

872.54.text: And then if that one works then we'll just

875.50.text: produce loads of those for the next batch.

877.91.text: So the tech demo one we had on this one for example

880.57.text: had double the field of view on the telescope.

883.47.text: We had gone up 3X in the number of pixels on the camera.

886.83.text: We had doubled the hard drive space on that satellite.

889.47.text: We had increased the radio speed.

891.26.text: We had put new sensors in that helped

893.04.text: us to do better attitude control,

896.85.text: And so we keep on iterating the technology.

898.11.text: We call this strapping space to Moore's Law.

900.58.text: We're basically trying to leverage the billions of dollars that have

903.99.text: gone into consumer electronics and stuff them into our satellites.

907.80.text: And although that seems pretty obvious that's not really

912.00.text: what the space industry has been doing until now.

915.81.text: It might be obvious to you and I,

918.37.text: but it's not what has been going on.

921.32.text: So basically there is traditionally you can only put something

925.06.text: into space if it has already been tested in space,

928.21.text: which leads to this sort of chicken and egg then everything is antiquated

931.58.text: and there is very long design life cycles for these things,

935.64.text: so they want them to last long times so they want reliable

937.69.text: technology and they design them over many, many years.

940.50.text: So what ends up happening is that you end

944.16.text: So the processors on the latest mission on Mars is -- has

947.83.text: a 33 megahertz processor and a two megapixel camera,

951.20.text: because 20 years ago that was really hot shit.

955.89.text: I mean you can't even find a 33 megahertz

957.62.text: processor to go and stick into satellite.

959.73.text: They have to keep their own lines of processors

962.36.text: going to keep that stuff going.

963.66.text: So we strap our satellites to Moore's Law and then

968.41.text: we really also do another thing that's quite equally

971.28.text: important I think to keep our satellites agile.

974.30.text: We keep on uploading new code.

976.18.text: Again, pretty obvious to computer programmers

979.70.text: down here on terra firma but,

982.00.text: in the aerospace sector there is always hesitation because

986.46.text: you could put up new code and it could send the satellite

991.06.text: So people are scared about doing that and at NASA

993.37.text: we would take -- typically take about a year for us

995.28.text: to get new code uploaded to our satellites.

998.68.text: So we just upload new code to our satellites all the time.

1008.97.text: So we take an agile approach to our software development as well.

1015.31.text: So we take - that's agile aerospace.

1357.91.text: So the real key thing that matters here is change,

1364.83.text: because what does daily imaging of the whole planet do,

2871.05.text: so that we can take the data of it regularly

2874.66.text: enough to do something about it.

2877.37.text: Most of you guys are engineers and you probably

2879.73.text: know that in order to effect a system,

2883.91.text: you have to take data about it on faster than

2886.33.text: the timescale of change of that system.

2889.54.text: you need to take data on how you're tumbling on faster

2892.07.text: than the timescale of the tumbling, kind of obvious.

2898.21.text: we're not taking data on a fast enough timescale of

2901.48.text: all the things that we're affecting the planet with.

2904.59.text: And so if you take imagery, of say once a year of the planet,

2907.59.text: but deforestation is happening on days and weeks,

2912.65.text: By trying to get us data that happens on a daily basis we

2915.74.text: hope to get inside that decision-making loop such that we

2918.03.text: can help us to steer and steward the planet better.

2921.58.text: But I think we'll be one of many companies doing that kind of thing,

2924.81.text: so I put us in that sort of perspective.

2926.80.text: I also put us in the perspective of

2929.50.text: the last point I was talking about,

2931.05.text: this is about this is the macroscopic challenge of our times,

2939.94.text: We have already wiped out a massive fraction

2942.27.text: of the species on this planet.

2943.88.text: That's why it's called the sixth major extinction event that

2946.08.text: we have done in the last sort of hundred years and we need

2949.69.text: to do something about that and this is the macroscopic challenge

2952.36.text: of our time and I really hope that we as a company fit into

2955.47.text: that by helping us to get us the data that we need.

2957.64.text: And just to give a very concrete example,

2960.26.text: in Nepal we actually donated all of our imagery of Nepal to

2965.06.text: the aid efforts that were going on over there and that's -- and

2969.13.text: actually just a couple of days ago we heard back that we had

2974.46.text: found two -- basically there was a crowd source campaign to look

2977.39.text: through our imagery and find where problems had happened,

2979.57.text: where mudslides had gone on and so forth and there were two villages

2983.46.text: that were found or towns that were found that weren't on the maps

2987.03.text: of all the aid agencies and now are getting relief effort,

2992.92.text: but that's something that I think is nice,

2996.63.text: and really the whole reason why we started the company.

3000.97.text: In case you guys have any interest in working at Planet,

3003.85.text: we do have lots of jobs.

3005.86.text: So and just to tell you just a tiny bit about ourselves,

3009.64.text: we are a very open collaborative culture.

3014.16.text: Stanford does currently have the most.

3017.73.text: We just checked, I just checked before this talk.

3021.28.text: so be warned that you might be being beaten out by MIT soon.

3025.95.text: Anyway, so we have a lot of talks like today Phil

3032.88.text: Rosedale who started Second Life came around.

3034.78.text: Last week Al Gore came around and talked to us.

3037.22.text: We have an interesting speakers come by and tell us about what they're

3040.00.text: interested in and how it relates to our data and so forth.

3043.80.text: And we do cool projects like that Nepal thing was

3046.42.text: just a few people getting together and going okay

3048.57.text: what can we do to help the situation in Nepal,

3050.70.text: we must able to do something and did.

3053.11.text: So if you have any interest in joining us,

3055.74.text: we do have internships this summer and in general.

3059.17.text: And permanent jobs and just e-mail people@planet.com

3063.90.text: if you're interested in a job.

3067.18.text: With that, I'll open it up for any questions.

3073.99.text: So we have got time for five minutes apparently.

3076.65.text: I think it's really cool how you've kind of gotten away

3080.01.text: from the large scale like big expensive satellites.

3084.38.text: You're kind of getting that rapid growth iteration going.

3088.36.text: But it seems like that would have ramifications

3091.01.text: for the lifetime of the satellites as well,

3092.22.text: but maybe you could replace them a lot faster.

3094.74.text: So when you see the lifetime,

3097.20.text: especially with electronics and Moore's Law you mentioned that,

3100.40.text: this is something that you can get better at.

3102.96.text: So essentially what happens to the lifetime of

3104.87.text: the satellite if we take this rapid approach?

3106.30.text: So we put our satellites -- most of our satellite lifetime

3111.51.text: is dictated by orbit altitude and depending on the orbit

3114.07.text: altitude they last sort of one to three years.

3116.96.text: And we -- our optimal orbit is around three years,

3120.92.text: because actually by that point Moore's Law has

3123.32.text: gone on and the satellites become obsolete.

3126.02.text: And other than that we want to keep them as low as possible

3128.89.text: to get a good resolution per unit satellite.

3131.61.text: So that would be our aim and so that's different from the sort of traditional

3139.02.text: model of trying to get your satellite lasting 10 or 20 years.

3169.78.text: The question is what other technologies are you guys

3172.41.text: going to dish out other than just the satellite?

3174.86.text: Well the satellites is quite enough for now.

3178.74.text: But surely I think we would love to collaborate with people doing drones

3184.88.text: and other sorts of satellite systems to integrate the datasets.

3188.91.text: I think that there is a lot of utility in merging

3192.27.text: these datasets from different -- I mean,

3193.88.text: obviously drones can do much higher resolution imagery for example,

3200.80.text: Agriculture is 26% of the world's land area,

3204.30.text: you can't very well cover that with drones,

3205.77.text: you'd need a ridiculous number of them, right.

3208.59.text: But if you have a building site and something has changed,

3210.93.text: you might want to send a drone in to see it,

3213.30.text: because you want to know brick by brick how many bricks have changed.

3216.63.text: So it depends on the use case,

3219.14.text: but I think they can be very complementary and they

3220.81.text: should be sort of on the same sort of place.

3222.88.text: I have to think that at some point proactively

3226.54.text: or reactively the military knocks at your door.

3229.01.text: Can you comment at all on the dialogue on that,

3233.24.text: pluses and minuses and how you go about that?

3239.34.text: Yes, of course some branches of the government,

3242.82.text: the military and intelligence communities are very interested

3245.61.text: in our data and from lots of different countries.

3249.12.text: And the way we talk to those guys is they can have our data

3254.80.text: the same as anyone else on the same sort of terms and that's --

3258.45.text: but yes a lot of those guys have approached us.

3262.64.text: Our main aim is to serve the humanitarian and commercial side,

3266.43.text: but we do want to be equal -- give our

3270.43.text: data to everyone that comes to us.

3274.83.text: No, they have not tried to restrict the data, no.

3280.99.text: Modifying on the question earlier now if miniturization

3286.49.text: What other applications could you imagine

3291.92.text: Oh well, so we could go into communication satellites,

3294.81.text: we could do GPS satellites, we could do radar satellites,

3297.67.text: there is lots of different things.

3299.54.text: I think we might be interested in doing that in the long haul,

3303.40.text: but right now we are sort of laser focused

3309.52.text: So very great mention of doing good to the planet,

3315.70.text: but have you thought about that your data can be used by terrorists,

3325.76.text: Yes, oh sorry, I forget to repeat the question.

3327.61.text: The question was could our data be used

3329.16.text: in a bad way for example by terrorists?

3330.95.text: Absolutely, we've thought a great deal about this.

3335.03.text: We started this company from a do-good position and as

3340.65.text: with any technology there is good and bad uses of it.

3346.46.text: The vast majority of the use cases of our

3349.42.text: imagery are positive in my opinion,

3351.67.text: having thought through the long list that I could

3354.26.text: come up with and if that were not the case,

3357.07.text: I wouldn't be pursuing the technology at all.

3358.89.text: I think it's really important that we all take responsibility

3361.84.text: for deciding what technologies to focus on based on their

3365.46.text: use and whether it's really a net positive.

3369.05.text: However, yes there are bad uses of our satellite

3372.44.text: imagery that I'm sure will come about.

3374.89.text: And all I can say is that we will do our best to try

3379.35.text: and restrict those negative uses as best we can.

3386.86.text: You brushed over the fact that you can't right now see people,

3389.77.text: but you also said that more Moore's Law relates to you guys,

3393.95.text: so I can clearly see that in 10 years you guys would

3397.31.text: be seeing who's going bald before they know it.

3403.17.text: Let me give you a bit of a reason why.

3406.05.text: I mean, fundamentally our resolution is dictated by the optic

3409.25.text: size and even the largest satellites that ever get launched

3413.64.text: which are bus-sized satellites costing billions of dollars,

3417.57.text: the limit of the size of the optic is limited by

3419.61.text: the size of the rocket that is carrying them.

3422.74.text: And that is normally 4 to 5 meters wide.

3425.70.text: And even if you take that,

3426.91.text: you can only get down to sort of 10 centimeter

3432.61.text: With 10 centimeters pixels you can't see someone.

3434.61.text: So even with those bigger satellites you

3437.02.text: can't really see or identify people.

3439.85.text: That doesn't mean you can't do some things like track vehicles.

3442.78.text: So there is not like the zero implications for privacy,

3445.43.text: but I think it's extraordinarily difficult to get to that sort

3448.61.text: of level that would be necessary to actually identify people.

3455.27.text: You mentioned that you've previously worked on getting rid

3459.59.text: of space debris and I was wondering after the life cycle of

3462.75.text: these for one to three years is there a way around that?

3468.10.text: So what I thought after contributing to getting rid of space debris,

3471.17.text: I would contribute some more space debris.

3472.89.text: So that was why we began the company.

3476.57.text: Yes, so what happens is that,

3477.87.text: that -- the space debris is a real problem and there's about 30 million

3481.06.text: pieces of orbital space debris orbiting the Earth today,

3483.95.text: manmade debris of which -- most of which we can't track even,

3488.78.text: So it's a real problem and in particular above about 800 kilometers

3493.39.text: between 800 and 1200 kilometers where the main density is,

3496.36.text: where most people have put their satellites over some of history,

3499.94.text: it's got so dense that now there's a runaway cascade

3504.24.text: where the collisions between debris and satellites

3507.24.text: and debris and debris are creating more debris,

3509.86.text: because every time they collide they create lots

3512.58.text: of little bits then the debris is coming down,

3515.13.text: such that we're in a runaway cascade in that thing.

3518.20.text: We keep our satellites way below that like 400 to

3522.00.text: 500 kilometers where there is enough atmospheric

3524.43.text: drag that it just pulls the satellites down.

3526.53.text: So the simple answer is that they just come down really quickly

3529.52.text: and they can't possibly contribute to this long-term challenge.

3533.08.text: But we would love eventually to try and mitigate

3536.31.text: that problem that's up higher altitude, because if we don't,

3540.24.text: we'll have a serious dilemma on our hands

3542.29.text: about utilizing space in the long haul.

3544.75.text: A bit like climate change the sooner you nip it

3546.85.text: in the bud the better and so when I was at NASA,

3549.11.text: I was working on schemes to try and do

3550.86.text: the nipping in the bud if you like.

3552.32.text: You mean they fall randomly back to Earth?

3558.97.text: Well, they decay in a fairly predictable way based on the altitude

3563.89.text: and sort of the atmosphere has an exponential density with altitude

3568.66.text: and so well depending on the altitude we put them that,

3572.06.text: we know pretty well how long they're going to last.

3574.52.text: It also depends of course which way we're pointed.

3576.42.text: And I assume they burn up?

3578.79.text: And they burn up in the upper atmosphere.

3581.63.text: No, they do not fall on people's heads.

3582.94.text: I have to worry about them hitting me on the head.

3585.23.text: I'm going to guess that all of you found this absolutely inspiring.

3588.95.text: Please join me in welcoming Will Marshall.
